title: The End of Tipping: Will Danny Meyer's Move Crumble the Gratuity?
text:
A Direct Path to a Strong Credit Score Via Your Rent Payments 
“Restaurants typically operate on slim profit margins, usually around 3 to 6%,” she told MainStreet. " In order to subsidize an increase in wages, restaurants operating on thin margins will, more often than not, need to increase menu prices. With over one million restaurants nationwide, the competition is stiff so striking a balance while ensuring a dining experience that encourages patrons to return is important to the survival of the restaurant.” "Americans," she added, "overwhelmingly support keeping the tipping model intact." (An observation borne out, in fact, by science .) 
Considered from that light, it’s unsurprising that this experiment has so far been limited to top-tier restaurants and their diners who are relatively unconcerned about menu prices. Danny Meyer, a successful restaurateur in New York City who also founded Shake Shack, is moving to get rid of tipp... in TheStreet's Hangs on LockerDome It’s all well and good for businessmen like Meyer to lead the charge in New York’s upper echelons, but if tipping is going to disappear at the local greasy spoon, diners will have to change their minds about the practice of tipping.
They should, too, because ending the era of the tip would make life incalculably easier for everyone, starting with calculating difficult bills . Factoring 18% into a shared bill is a mathematical headache and one of the worst parts of going out for dinner with a large group of friends. It’s a stress that absolutely nobody needs, especially not at the end of a big meal.
